{{short description|1966 film directed by John Ford}} {{redirect|Seven Women}} {{Infobox film | name = 7 Women | image = 7 Women 1966 poster.jpg | image_size = 220px | caption = 1966 theatrical poster by [[Reynold Brown]] | director = [[John Ford]] | producer = [[Bernard Smith (editor)|Bernard Smith]]
John Ford | writer = [[Janet Green (screenwriter)|Janet Green]]
John McCormick | based on = {{based on|short story "Chinese Finale"|[[Norah Lofts]]}} | narrator = | starring = [[Anne Bancroft]]
[[Margaret Leighton]]
[[Flora Robson]]
[[Sue Lyon]] | music = [[Elmer Bernstein]] | cinematography = [[Joseph LaShelle]] | editing = [[Otho Lovering]] | distributor = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | released = {{film date|1966|1|5|Los Angeles}} | runtime = 87 min. | country = United States | language = English
Mandarin | budget = $2.3 millionNat Segaloff, ''Final Cuts: The Last Films of 50 Great Directors'', Bear Manor Media, 2013, p.103-105, {{ISBN|978-1593932336}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''7 Women''''', also known as '''''Seven Women''''', is a 1966 [[drama (film and television)|drama film]] directed by [[John Ford]] and starring [[Anne Bancroft]], [[Sue Lyon]], [[Margaret Leighton]], [[Flora Robson]], [[Mildred Dunnock]], [[Betty Field]], [[Anna Lee]], with [[Eddie Albert]], [[Mike Mazurki]] and [[Woody Strode]]. Made by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]], it was produced by Bernard Smith and John Ford, from a screenplay by [[Janet Green (screenwriter)|Janet Green]] and [[John McCormick (screenwriter)|John McCormick]], based on the short story "Chinese Finale" by [[Norah Lofts]]. The music score was by [[Elmer Bernstein]] and the cinematography by [[Joseph LaShelle]]. This was the last feature film directed by Ford, ending a career that spanned approximately fifty years. ==Plot== In rural [[Republic of China (1912-1949)|China]], in 1935, all but one of the white residents of a remote Christian mission post are women. The strict Miss Agatha Andrews ([[Margaret Leighton]]) is the head of the mission, assisted by the meek Miss Argent ([[Mildred Dunnock]]). Charles Pether ([[Eddie Albert]]) is a mission teacher who always wanted to be a [[pastor]]; his peevish, panicky, self-centred and domineering middle-aged wife Florrie ([[Betty Field]]) is pregnant for the first time. Emma Clark ([[Sue Lyon]]) is the only young staff member, whom Miss Andrews treats as if she was her daughter. The mission is elated to learn that a much-needed doctor is arriving. However, they are shocked to discover that Dr. Cartwright ([[Anne Bancroft]]) is a [[New York City|New York]] woman who smokes, drinks alcohol, swears, wears pants and short hair, disdains religion and sits before grace. She and Miss Andrews are soon at odds. Emma, who has led a very sheltered life, is fascinated by the newcomer, much to Miss Andrews's dismay. After she has settled in, Dr. Cartwright urges Miss Andrews to provide money to send Florrie Pether to a modern facility, as her age means that giving birth is high risk, but Andrews refuses. Meanwhile, there are rumors of atrocities committed by the militia of [[Mongols|Mongolian]] [[warlord]] Tunga Khan ([[Mike Mazurki]]). Miss Andrews is certain that the mission will be safe, as they are American citizens. After a nearby, even poorer British mission is sacked by Tunga Khan, Miss Andrews reluctantly accepts survivors Miss Binns ([[Flora Robson]]), Mrs. Russell ([[Anna Lee]]) and Miss Ling (Jane Chang), but only for a short time, as she is unwilling to harbor those of any other denomination for long. Immediately after the arrival of the survivors, a [[cholera]] outbreak erupts. Dr. Cartwright quickly takes command, treating all the Chinese of the area. Miss Andrews's initial hostility to her subsides when Emma gets sick and she implores Dr. Cartwright to save her life. After the emergency is over and Emma is well again, the relationship between Andrews and Cartwright starts to soften. but deteriorates when Cartwright shows up drunk in the dining room with a bottle of whiskey, and tries to make all the pious women drink as well. One night, Charles and Cartwright see a fire on the horizon and hear gunfire. The next morning, the Chinese soldiers of the nearby garrison evacuate in a hurry, as Tunga Khan and his men are believed to be approaching. Miss Andrews is still convinced the mision is untouchable, but Charles is now determined to be assertive. He and Kim, an English speaking male Chinese mission staff member, drive out to investigate the situation, while urging everyone else to be prepared to leave the mission, despite Miss Andrews's opposition. After a while, they hear the car's horn, but once the gate is opened, bandits on horseback charge in firing their guns and quickly take over the mission. Before being executed by the bandits, Kim tells the women Charles was murdered when he tried to rescue a woman being assaulted by Tunga Khan's men. Then Miss Ling, coming from a powerful [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|Mandarin]] family, is taken away to act as Tunga Khan's young wife's servant, while the seven white women are herded into a shed. They watch as Tunga Khan has every Chinese in the mission executed, women and children included, to Emma's shock. Tunga Khan comes into the shed and tries to take Emma. Realizing that they are mostly American women, he decides to ask for a ransom. With Miss Andrews panicking and Florrie in labor, Dr. Cartwright asks for her desperately needed [[medical bag]]. Tunga Khan offers to exchange it for her sexual submission to him. The doctor agrees, and helps Florrie give birth to a baby boy. After Cartwright goes to fulfill her end of the bargain, an increasingly deranged Andrews vilifies her, calling her "whore of Babylon". The others, however, understand the sacrifice the doctor has made and why. In the evening, the Mongols gather in a circle and organize wrestling matches for entertainment, with Dr. Cartwright watching the spectacle at Tunga Khan's side, as his new concubine. When the lean warrior ([[Woody Strode]]) who had been ogling Cartwright all evening steps into the ring to face the winner of a bout, Tunga Khan insists on accepting the challenge himself and breaks the man's neck. Cartwright manages to convince Tunga Khan to let the other women go, including Miss Ling. Before Miss Argent leaves, she sees the doctor hide a bottle that she had earlier called poison. She urges Cartwright not to do what she is planning, but to no avail. With the others safely away, Cartwright, now in a [[geisha]] outfit, goes to Tunga Khan's room and secretly poisons two drinks. She subserviently offers a cup to Tunga Khan, as she utters, "So long, ya bastard." After Tunga Khan drinks, he immediately keels over dead. Then, after a moment's hesitation, Cartwright drinks from the second cup. ==Cast== * [[Anne Bancroft]] as Dr. D. R. Cartwright * [[Sue Lyon]] as Emma Clark, Mission Staff * [[Margaret Leighton]] as Agatha Andrews, Head of Mission * [[Flora Robson]] as Miss Binns, Head of British Mission * [[Mildred Dunnock]] as Jane Argent, Andrews' Assistant * [[Betty Field]] as Mrs. Florrie Pether, Charles' pregnant wife * [[Anna Lee]] as Mrs. Russell, Mission Staff * [[Eddie Albert]] as Charles Pether, Mission Teacher * [[Mike Mazurki]] as Tunga Khan, Bandit Leader * [[Woody Strode]] as Lean Warrior * Jane Chang as Miss Ling, Mission Staff * Hans William Lee as Kim, Mission Staff * H. W. Gim as Coolie * [[Irene Tsu]] as Chinese Girl ==Acclaim== The film also appeared in several lists. These include: * Most Misappreciated American Films of All Time (1977, [[Andrew Sarris]]) * Most Misappreciated American Films of All Time (1977, [[Pascal Bonitzer]]) * Most Misappreciated American Films of All Time (1977, [[Serge Daney]]) * Most Important American Films (1977, [[Enno Patalas]]) * Most Important American Films (1977, [[Luc Moullet]]) * Genre Favorites: Adventure (1993) * Alternative Choices to [[Sight and Sound]]'s 360 Films Classics List (1998) * 100 Essential Films (2003–Present, [[Slant Magazine]]) * Favorite Films (1975, [[Syndicat Francais de la Critique de Cinema]]) ''[[Cahiers du cinéma]]'' voted it the 6th best film of 1966{{cite web | title = Cahiers du Cinema Top 10's - 1966 | url= http://alumnus.caltech.edu/~ejohnson/critics/cahiers.html#y1966 | website=Alumnus.caltech.eduaccessdate =12 October 2015}} and [[Andrew Sarris]] rated it the third-best of 1966 (only being beaten by ''[[Blow-up]]'' and ''[[Gertrud (film)|Gertrud]]'').{{cite web | title = Andrew Sarris Top 10's - 1966 | url= http://alumnus.caltech.edu/~ejohnson/critics/sarris.html#y1966|website=Alumnue.caltech.edu | accessdate =12 October 2015}} The film is currently ranked #847 on the ''They Shoot Pictures, Don't They?'' (TSPDT) list of the 1000 greatest films of all time. The list is based on a poll of 1,825 [[film critics]], scholars, and cinephiles, as well as a culling of over 900 existing "greatest film" lists. ==Production== The original story, ''Chinese Finale'', was presented as an episode of ''[[Alcoa Theatre]]'' in March 1960 with [[Hilda Plowright]] as Miss Andrews and [[Jan Sterling]] as Dr. Mary Cartwright.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0507866/|title=Alcoa Theatre (1957–1960) : Chinese Finale|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=2016-07-18}} John Ford considered both [[Katharine Hepburn]] and [[Jennifer Jones]] for the role of Dr. Cartwright, and [[Rosalind Russell]] lobbied for the part, but eventually [[Patricia Neal]] was cast. Ford began the film on 8 February 1965 on the MGM backlot, but after three days of filming, Neal had a stroke. [[Anne Bancroft]] took over the role of Dr. Cartwright but Ford was unhappy with Bancroft and called her "the mistress of monotone".p. 332 Davis,Ronald L. ''John Ford: Hollywood's Old Master'' University of Oklahoma Press, 1997 Ford originally considered [[Carol Lynley]] for the role played in the film by MGM contract star [[Sue Lyon]], whom the studio insisted on.{{cite web|title=ROLES THAT COULDA, SHOULDA BEEN: CAROL LYNLEY|url=http://sixtiescinema.com/2011/09/11/roles-that-coulda-shoulda-been-carol-lynley/|website=Sixties Cinema|accessdate=1 August 2017|date=September 11, 2011}} Shooting finished on April 12, only six days behind schedule. Ford chose [[Otho Lovering]] to edit the film; they had first worked together on ''[[Stagecoach (1939 film)|Stagecoach]]'' (1939). Lovering edited most of Ford's feature films in the 1960s. The film was not released until 1966. ==Analysis== As Ford was a devout Catholic, the film shows the difference between the claim of being moral and the act of morals; the stark contrast between compassion and sacrifice to the austere holier-than-thou philosophy.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdbeaver.com/film/articles/ten_underappreciated_john_ford_films.htm |title=Ten Underappreciated John Ford Films |website=Dvdbeaver.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303172920/http://www.dvdbeaver.com/film/articles/ten_underappreciated_john_ford_films.htm |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }} ==See also== *[[List of American films of 1966]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0060050|title=7 Women}} {{John Ford}} [[Category:1966 films]] [[Category:1960s drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Mandarin-language films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:Films scored by Elmer Bernstein]] [[Category:Films directed by John Ford]] [[Category:Films based on short fiction]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:Films set in 1935]] [[Category:Films set in China]]

{{Primary sources|date=November 2008}} {{Infobox Television episode | title = A Special Edition | series = The Outer Limits | image = | caption = | season = 3 | episode = 18 | airdate = 25 July 1997 | production = 62 | writer = [[Naren Shankar]] | director = [[Mario Azzopardi]] | photographer = | guests = [[Alan Thicke]] as Donald Rivers
[[Bruce Harwood]] as Dr. Avery Strong
[[Stevie Vallance|Louise Vallance]] as Sandra
Michael St. John Smith as Dr. Richard Morgan | episode_list = List of The Outer Limits episodes | prev = [[Feasibility Study (The Outer Limits)|Feasibility Study]] | next = [[Criminal Nature (The Outer Limits)|Criminal Nature]] }} "'''A Special Edition'''" is an episode of ''[[The Outer Limits (1995 TV series)|The Outer Limits]]'' television show. It was first broadcast on 25 July 1997, during the third season.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} ==Introduction== Donald Rivers, a [[journalist]] for the television show ''The Whole Truth'', has found proof that the government and large [[defense contractor]]s have been illegally and secretly [[cloning]] human beings. After locking himself in the studio with only a small crew, he plans to air his report to the world. ==Opening narration== {{cquote|''Sometimes, to uncover that which is hidden, we must first be made to look.''}} ==Plot== Rivers has the show of a lifetime: rock solid proof that the government and private defense contractors have been engaging in secret [[genetic cloning]] experiments. However, many mysterious and powerful forces are trying to stop him in order to keep their secrets. After fooling the forces by having a bum wear his hat and coat as a diversion, he goes on-air live, in a locked studio, accompanied only by his producer Sandra, a [[skeleton crew]] and Dr. Avery Strong, a live eyewitness to the history of the dark side of science. As he presents his evidence, the powerful begin to interfere. First, they try to block the transmission. Then, the spokewoman of the network's [[parent company]] named Colleen Winton disavows the show. When thugs with guns break down the studio door, Rivers continues the show on the fly, transmitting live from the back of the show's mobile unit. However, during this, another signal overrides theirs, showing a clone of Rivers giving a fraudulent report, saying that Dr. Strong went crazy and killed everyone but Rivers and his driver, who managed to escape. Shortly thereafter, clones walk into the van followed by the Rivers clone, who pulls a gun on the crew. Stating that the viewers are already starting to forget due to the "fraudulent report", the Rivers clone adds that no matter how influential he is, his show is just a show. Rivers, Strong, Sandra, and the skeleton crew are summarily shot to death by the Rivers clone. ==Closing narration== {{cquote|''We rely upon others to inform us but wisdom can never be taught... and we must always decide the truth for ourselves.''}} ==Trivia== * This episode is a [[clip show]] and Donald Rivers's reports are made up from clips from other episodes of ''The Outer Limits''. However, this episode is unusual because one clip came from an episode that had yet to be broadcast; the report that Rivers runs on Mason Stark did not air for another four episodes. Furthermore, given the ending of ''[[In Another Life (The Outer Limits)|In Another Life]]'', Rivers's claim to contact Stark's representatives establishes that every episode of ''The Outer Limits'' that fits in this continuity takes place on the reality where Stark developed the inter-dimensional technology and not the one in which he was killed. * Dr. Avery Strong is a brother of Randall Strong, a former member of Army intelligence, who tried to convince a high-level government committee that a number of different alien invasions of Earth were occurring, demanding an official investigation and response to those threats (''[[The Voice of Reason (The Outer Limits)|The Voice of Reason]]''). In this episode, Dr. Avery Strong tells us that his brother, Randall, was committed to an asylum. * Referenced episodes in order of the news report and the events that are mentioned in there: ** ''[[Last Supper (The Outer Limits)|Last Supper]]'' - The experiments done on Jade by Dr. Lawrence Sinclair to discover the secret of her immortality. ** ''[[New Lease (The Outer Limits)|New Lease]]'' - Dr. James Houghton and Dr. Charles McCamber's experiments on reviving the dead. ** ''[[Blood Brothers (The Outer Limits)|Blood Brothers]]'' - The Deighton C. Drug. ** ''[[The Voice of Reason (The Outer Limits)|The Voice of Reason]]'' - References to Randall's discovery of aliens. ** ''[[Afterlife (The Outer Limits)|Afterlife]]'' - Experiments involving alien DNA being injected into humans. ** ''[[In Another Life (The Outer Limits)|In Another Life]]'' - See above. ** ''[[Dark Rain (The Outer Limits)|Dark Rain]]'' - Footage of the episode ''[[Dark Rain (The Outer Limits)|Dark Rain]]'' is used out of context. It is used to show a video clip of babies that have been cloned and experimented on. In the actual ''Dark Rain'' story, these babies were mutants birthed by humans who were supposed to be sterile due to contamination. The babies in the original story are not clones at all or even vaguely referenced as clones, and ''Dark Rain'' clearly takes place on an [[alternate Earth]]. Also, the episode ''In Another Life'' is referenced showing multiple Starks even though there are numerous versions of him due to use of an inter-dimensional machine which has nothing to do with cloning at all. ==References== ==External links== * {{tv.com episode|the-outer-limits/a-special-edition-14997|A Special Edition}} * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0667855/ A Special Edition] at [[Internet Movie Database]] {{The Outer Limits}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Special Edition}} [[Category:The Outer Limits (1995 TV series season 3) episodes]] [[Category:1997 American television episodes]] [[Category:Clip shows]] [[Category:Mockumentaries]] [[Category:Genetic engineering in fiction]] [[Category:Cloning in fiction]] [[Category:Television in fiction]]

page.title: Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation

revision.comment: /* Patient database breach */ Added title to ref
revision.text:
{{update|date=August 2013}} {{cleanup|reason=dead links to expired domains|date=September 2013}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} The '''Adult Industry Medical Associates P.C.''' (formerly '''Adult Industry Medical Healthcare Foundation'''), also known simply as '''AIM''' or '''AIM Medical''', was an organization that [[STD testing|tested]] [[pornographic actor]]s for [[HIV]] and other [[Sexually transmitted disease|STD]]s on a scheduled basis. Tests for the sex industry actors were done at the Foundation's offices in [[San Fernando Valley]], [[Sherman Oaks, CA|Sherman Oaks]], and [[Granada Hills, CA|Granada Hills]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/17/us/hiv-cases-shut-down-pornography-film-industry-254380.html |title=H.I.V. Cases Shut Down Pornography Film Industry |work=New York Times |author=Nick Madigan |date=April 17, 2004 |accessdate=March 20, 2008 }} Each month, about 1,200 actors were tested for HIV, with results as early as 14 days after infection. This test is effective 10 days after potential infection, and anytime thereafter ([[HIV-1]] [[DNA]], by [[PCR]]) as compared to the alternative HIV test ([[Hiv_test#ELISA|HIV ELISA]]) which requires a six-month waiting period to be effective.{{cite web |url=https://www.sxcheck.com/view/test/GetTested/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080610153516/http://www.sxcheck.com/view/test/GetTested |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 10, 2008 |title=Test Selection – Comprehensive Panel – HIV/AIDS Premium Test |publisher=SxCheck |accessdate=March 20, 2008 }} Other tests include such STDs as [[Chlamydia infection|chlamydia]], [[gonorrhea]] and [[syphilis]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/02/opinion/how-to-put-condoms-in-the-picture-430110.html |title=How to Put Condoms in the Picture |work=New York Times |author=[[Sharon Mitchell]] |date=May 2, 2004 |accessdate=March 20, 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080229135313/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E6DF153DF931A35756C0A9629C8B63| archivedate= February 29, 2008 | deadurl= no}} AIM went out of business in 2011 after a lawsuit regarding violation of patient privacy. ==History== Since the 1980s, outbreaks of HIV/AIDS within the community of erotic actors caused a number of deaths. In response to this threat AIM was founded in 1998 by former adult entertainer [[Sharon Mitchell]], who had left the industry in 1996 to pursue credentials in public health counseling and [[sexology]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/10/us/voice-of-health-in-a-pornographic-world.html |title=Voice of Health in a Pornographic World |accessdate=February 26, 2007 |author=Nick Madigan |date=May 10, 2004 |work=New York Times |quote=
Sharon Mitchell — ''Well-behaved women rarely make history'' }} The Foundation helped set up a system in the U.S. wherein erotic actors in the [[adult film]] industry are tested for AIDS every 30 days. All on-camera sexual contact is logged, and a positive test result triggers the contacting and re-testing of all sexual partners during the previous three to six months. The Foundation provides secure means of sharing results via their web servers so that results cannot be forged. Prior to AIM, there had been STD testing programs in lifestyle communities, including [[Kerista Commune]], [[More University]], and [[Rajneeshpuram]]. These approaches had mixed results and were less systematic and regular. This system resulted in low rates of HIV transmission, and hence low rates of infection, among erotic actors: reportedly, not a single HIV test in an active adult industry performer had been positive in the four-year period prior to 2004.{{clarification needed|date=July 2017}}{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} It was in 2004 that AIM assisted in the sex-film-industry shutdown, a quarantine that lasted fewer than 60 days. A male performer, [[Darren James]], had tested positive for HIV in April and, to prevent another HIV outbreak, an urgent search was initiated for his potentially infected partners. A total of four more performers, [[Bianca Biaggi]], Jessica Dee, [[Lara Roxx]], and Miss Arroyo were diagnosed with the virus by the end of the testing rounds, including one unrelated case in New York.{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/30/us/new-hiv-infection-found-in-sex-film-industry.html|title= New H.I.V. Infection Found in Sex-Film Industry|accessdate=March 20, 2008|author= Nick Madigan|date= April 30, 2004|work=New York Times}} James had apparently had contact with 12 women since his initial negative HIV test in March upon his return from a [[Brazil]]ian film shoot.{{cite web|url=http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=22883 |title=Lara Roxx Timeline Begs Questions: Darren James got it from Lara Roxx, not the other way around? |author=Gene Ross |publisher=Adult FYI |date=May 27, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080313070354/http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=22883 |archivedate=March 13, 2008 }}{{cite news|url= http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-041604adult-g,1,4216028.graphic|title=Pyramid of potential infection|work=Los Angeles Times|date= April 16, 2004|accessdate=March 20, 2008|quote= Time line of potential first and second generation infections}} In 2009, the Los Angeles Public Health department and the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' claimed there were 16 unreported cases of HIV among adult film actors.{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2009/06/at-least-16-previously-unpublicized-hiv-cases-in-porn-film-performers-public-health-officials-say.html|title=At least 16 previously unpublicized HIV cases|work=Los Angeles Times|date= June 11, 2009|accessdate=June 11, 2009|quote= Los Angeles County officials released public health data this afternoon indicating that 16 previously unpublicized cases of HIV had been confirmed in adult film industry performers since 2004 when an outbreak shut down porn production for a month. | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090615065230/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2009/06/at-least-16-previously-unpublicized-hiv-cases-in-porn-film-performers-public-health-officials-say.html| archivedate= June 15, 2009 | deadurl= no}} AIM Health Care Foundation reported that these cases were actually members of the general public or people applying to work in the adult film industry that had not yet actually worked in films due to their initial test being positive.{{cite web|url= http://www.aim-med.org/news/2009/06/12/1244838040/|archive-url= https://archive.is/20090615083151/http://www.aim-med.org/news/2009/06/12/1244838040/|dead-url= yes|archive-date= June 15, 2009|title= News 6/12/09|publisher= AIM|date= June 12, 2009|accessdate=June 12, 2009|quote= This is why they are not "publicized" as they had never fulfilled the desire to work in Adult Entertainment, due to the positive test.}} On October 12, 2010, the Foundation reported that an actor or actress had been infected with HIV. The name and gender of the person was not released to the public.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/porn-actor-has-tested-positive-for-hiv-industry-clinic-officials-confirm.html|title=Porn Actor has Tested Positive for HIV; Industry Clinic Officials Confirm a Quarantine is in Effect|work=Los Angeles Times|date=October 12, 2010|accessdate=October 13, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101013025742/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com//lanow//2010//10//porn-actor-has-tested-positive-for-hiv-industry-clinic-officials-confirm.html| archivedate= October 13, 2010 | deadurl= no}} [[Vivid Entertainment]] and [[Wicked Pictures]] shut down porn production temporarily to avoid spreading of the virus. Although [[Wicked Pictures]] has a mandatory condom policy, the company shut down to wait for the [[quarantine]] list.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/wicked-pictures-suspends-production-as-precaution-following-new-hiv-case-in-porn-performer-.html|title=Wicked Pictures and Vivid Entertainment Suspend Production as a Precaution Amid New HIV Case in Porn Performer|work=Los Angeles Times|date=October 12, 2010|accessdate=October 13, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101016193546/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/wicked-pictures-suspends-production-as-precaution-following-new-hiv-case-in-porn-performer-.html| archivedate= October 16, 2010 | deadurl= no}} In early 2011, the [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]] publicly raised questions about AIM clinics' licensing situation, resulting in a shutdown. Later that year, the foundation reopened under private ownership, but this was short-lived.{{cite web|last1=Stevens|first1=Sara|title=Adult Industry Medical Healthcare Foundation|url=https://www.stdaware.com/std-resource-center/orgs/adult-industry-medical-healthcare-foundation|publisher=STDAware|accessdate=21 July 2017|language=en}} ==SxCheck== In 2006, AIM started offering online services for selecting, scheduling, and paying for tests in affiliation with local clinics and laboratories in many cities via the [http://www.sxcheck.com SxCheck] (alternatively AIM Check) website.{{cite web |url = http://sxcheck.com/AskMitch/ |title = Ask Dr Mitch |author = Sharon Mitchell |publisher = SxCheck |accessdate = March 20, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080322073821/http://sxcheck.com/AskMitch/ |archivedate = March 22, 2008 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }} With secure online access to test results, faking of paper test results was prevented, since clients could select to privately share the results with others online, by email, or by SMS.{{cite web |url=https://www.sxcheck.com/view/test/About/ |title=About SxCheck – Physical Barriers |publisher=Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation |accessdate=March 20, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Patient database breach== AIM Medical's patient [[database]] was the source of a massive 2011 [[Data breach|data leak]] containing confidential personal information, including the [[Personal name|real names]] of over 12,000 pornographic actors and their [[sexually transmitted diseases|STD]] test results, which was distributed via the [[Porn Wikileaks]] website.{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/#!5787392/porn-star-hiv-test-database-leaked |title=Gawker |accessdate=2015-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111012203/http://gawker.com/ |archivedate=January 11, 2015 |df=mdy }}{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2011/03/31/california-health-clinic-reportedly-releases-porn-actors-personal-information/ | work=Fox News | title=Porn Actors' Personal Information, HIV Status Released Through California Health Clinic, Report Says | date=March 31, 2011}} AIM closed its offices and filed for [[bankruptcy]] in May 2011 as a result of a privacy lawsuit challenging AIM's handling of the patient records. Circa: Donald Carlos Seoane aka Donny Long former HIV actor releases database informations clarifications, pcr/dna results etc. #02-15-80 / 590-76-3960 pornwikileaks http://thegaymafia.ml/ {{cite web|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2011/05/porn_clinic_closed_aim_testing.php|title=Porn Clinic AIM Closes For Good: Valley-Based Industry Scrambles to Find New STD Testing System|last=Dennis Romero|date=May 3, 2011|work=[[LA Weekly]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Williams|first=Mitchell|title=How a Straight Adult Performer Convinced Me That Condoms Are Useless in Porn|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mitchell-williams/how-a-straight-adult-performer-convinced-me-that-condoms-are-useless-in-porn_b_2165066.html|publisher=Huffington Press|accessdate=18 February 2014}} ==See also== * [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]] * [[HIV/AIDS in the pornographic film industry]] * [[Performer Availability Screening Services]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * {{cite web |url= http://www.aim-med.org |title= Official Website |dead-url= yes |archive-date= February 3, 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110203165827/http://www.aim-med.org/ |access-date= February 11, 2006 |df= mdy-all }} [[Category:HIV/AIDS organizations]] [[Category:Sex industry in the United States]] [[Category:American pornography]] [[Category:1998 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1998]] [[Category:2011 disestablishments in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 2011]] [[Category:STDs in the sex industry]]

''(Macedonian: Домаќине, ожени се!)'' * Evening with Vesna ''(Macedonian: Вечер со Весна - ток шоу)'' * One kiss - Top list ''(Macedonian: Еден бакнеж - Топ листа)'' * Labor Action ''(Macedonia: Работна акција - реалити шоу)'' * Mission [Im]possible ''(Macedonian: [Не]возможна мисија)'' * Down, Down ''(Macedonian: Зајди, зајди)'' * Show of all times ''(Macedonian: Шоу на сите времиња)'' * One on One ''(Macedonian: Еден на еден)'' {{colend}} ===Foreign TV Shows=== {{colbegin}} * [[Avenida Brasil (telenovela)|Brazil Avenue]] ''(Macedonia: Авенија на љубовта)'' * Stolen Love ''(Macedonian: Украдена љубов'') * Secrets ''(Macedonian: Тајни)'' * Sisters ''(Macedonian: Сестри)'' * Jurnal of Feride ''(Macedonian: Дневникот на Фериде)'' * [[The Company (TV miniseries)|The Company]] ''(Macedonian: Компанијата)'' * Mahmut and Meriem ''(Macedonian: Махмут и Мерием)'' * Folk ''(Macedonian: Фолк)'' * Abyss of love ''(Macedonian: Амбис на љубовта)'' * [[Na Aana Is Des Laado|Rejected]] ''(Macedonian: Отфрлена)'' {{colend}} ===Documentary=== {{colbegin}} * Alfa action (Macedonian:Алфа акција) * Unit (Macedonian: Единица) * Unaired stories (Macedonian: Необјавени приказни) * Family secrets (Macedonian: Семејни тајни - нова сезона) * Miscalls of Jesus (Macedonian: Чудата на Исус) * Atenbrough: 60 years if the wild (Macedonian: Атенбороу: 60 години во дивината) * Ice planet (Macedonian: Ледена планета) * [[Europe: A Natural History]] (Macedonian: Дивата Европа) * Opus Dei - Code of DaVinci (Macedonian: Опус Деи - Кодот на Да Винчи) * Survival - Marine sniper (Macedonian: Преживување - Маринец снајперист) {{colend}} ==External links== {{Empty section|date=August 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Macedonian media |state=collapsed}} [[Category:Television in the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Media in the Republic of Macedonia]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Anup Jalota|Anup Jalota]] ([[User talk:Anup Jalota|talk]]) to last version by XLinkBot
revision.text:
{{Infobox YouTube personality | name = All India Bakchod Ltd. | image = All India Bakchod.jpg | occupation = Comedians | website = [http://allindiabakchod.in/ Official Website] | pseudonym = AIB | channel_name = AllIndiaBakchod | founded = 2012 | Ended = 2018 | subscribers = 3.3 million subscribers | subscriber_date = 28th August 2018 | views = 403,325,378 views | view_date = 12th July 2018 | associated_acts = Rohan Joshi, Ashish Shakya | silver_button = yes | gold_button = yes }} '''All India Bakchod''' ('''AIB''') is an Indian comedy group. It was founded by [[Gursimran Khamba]] and [[Tanmay Bhat]] who were later joined by Rohan Joshi. The group maintains a [[YouTube]] channel that shows their comedy sketches and parodies on topics such as politics, Indian culture, and society, and the [[Bollywood|Hindi film industry]]. Initially, the group produced [[podcasts]] and from 2013, they started using YouTube as a medium to share their comic work.{{cite web|last1=Chakraborty|first1=Shruti|title=Can YouTube sensation All India Bakchod laugh its way to the bank?|url=http://qz.com/265078/can-youtube-sensation-all-india-bakchod-laugh-its-way-to-the-bank/|website=QZ|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=16 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141028143329/http://qz.com/265078/can-youtube-sensation-all-india-bakchod-laugh-its-way-to-the-bank/#|archive-date=2014-10-28|dead-url=no|df=}} It is one of the most viewed, India-based channel on YouTube. Joshi said that the reason for their use of YouTube was that they simply did not have funds for advertisements and other promotional materials, and instead relied upon social media to promote their work.{{cite news|last1=Nathan|first1=Archana|title=Jokes apart...|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/magazine/stand-up-comedy-jokes-apart/article6510836.ece|accessdate=2 November 2014|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=18 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141019035005/http://www.thehindu.com/features/magazine/stand-up-comedy-jokes-apart/article6510836.ece#|archive-date=2014-10-19|dead-url=no|df=}} On October 8th 2018, founders Khamba and Bhat were forced to step away from AIB amid sexual harassment allegations.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/comedian-tanmay-bhat-to-step-away-from-association-with-aib-says-comedy-group-amid-metoo-allegations-1928627|title=Comedian Tanmay Bhat To "Step Away" From AIB Amid #MeToo Allegations|work=NDTV.com|access-date=2018-10-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008131348/https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/comedian-tanmay-bhat-to-step-away-from-association-with-aib-says-comedy-group-amid-metoo-allegations-1928627#|archive-date=2018-10-08|dead-url=no|df=}} {{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/india/1416948/metoo-india-aibs-tanmay-bhat-hindustan-times-journalist-quit/|title=India’s #MeToo wave is already forcing powerful men out of their jobs|work=NDTV.com|access-date=2018-10-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008171208/https://qz.com/india/1416948/metoo-india-aibs-tanmay-bhat-hindustan-times-journalist-quit/#|archive-date=2018-10-08|dead-url=no|df=}} ==Work== In 2014, AIB teamed up with actress [[Alia Bhatt]] to make a 10-minute sketch called "Genius of the Year", which made fun of Bhatt's ''[[Koffee with Karan]]'' interview. Directed by [[Shakun Batra]], the video also had spoofs of her movie songs. As of May 2018, the group had amassed over 379 million views on their videos and had 3.1 million subscribers on [[YouTube]].{{cite news|last1=Sengupta|first1=Devina|title=New startups in comedy business step up hiring as humour delights|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/New-startups-in-comedy-business-step-up-hiring-as-humour-delights/articleshow/38990134.cms|accessdate=2 November 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=25 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209000804/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/New-startups-in-comedy-business-step-up-hiring-as-humour-delights/articleshow/38990134.cms#|archive-date=2014-12-09|dead-url=no|df=}} In December 2014, AIB organized a [[Roast (comedy)|roast]] show, ''[[All India Bakchod Knockout Championship]]'' featuring [[Karan Johar]] as the host with [[Ranveer Singh]] and [[Arjun Kapoor]] as subjects of the roast.{{cite web | url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/141111/entertainment-tvmusic/article/arjun-kapoor-ranveer-singh-all-india-bakchod-knockout | title=Arjun Kapoor, Ranveer Singh in All India Bakchod Knockout | publisher=Deccan Chronicle | date=12 November 2014 | accessdate=29 January 2015 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150130172646/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/141111/entertainment-tvmusic/article/arjun-kapoor-ranveer-singh-all-india-bakchod-knockout# | archive-date=2015-01-30 | dead-url=no | df= }}{{cite web | url=http://www.asianage.com/bollywood/all-india-bakchod-boys-roast-arjun-kapoor-ranveer-singh-768 | title=All India Bakchod boys to roast Arjun Kapoor, Ranveer Singh | publisher=The Asian Age | date=16 December 2014 | accessdate=29 January 2015 | author=Murthy, Sushmita | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150130172718/http://www.asianage.com/bollywood/all-india-bakchod-boys-roast-arjun-kapoor-ranveer-singh-768# | archive-date=2015-01-30 | dead-url=no | df= }} The event is claimed to have raised over 40 lakh [[Indian rupee|rupee]]s for charity organisations such as [[Being Human (NGO)|Being Human]] and Vogue Empower (which works for women empowerment).{{cite web | url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/entertainment-others/ranveer-singhs-pda-with-rumoured-girlfriend-deepika-padukone-and-kiss-with-karan-johar/ | title=Ranveer Singh’s PDA with rumoured girlfriend Deepika Padukone and kiss with Karan Johar | publisher=The Indian Express | date=22 December 2014 | accessdate=29 January 2015 | author=Gera, Sonal | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207151756/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/entertainment-others/ranveer-singhs-pda-with-rumoured-girlfriend-deepika-padukone-and-kiss-with-karan-johar/# | archive-date=2015-02-07 | dead-url=no | df= }} They also perform regular stand-up acts across the globe. AIB also has an advertisement wing called Vigyapanti, which was started in early October 2015.{{Cite web|title = The joke’s not just on You(Tube) - Mumbai Mirror -|url = http://www.mumbaimirror.com/others/sunday-read/The-jokes-not-just-on-YouTube/articleshow/49433084.cms|website = Mumbai Mirror|accessdate = 2015-10-26|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151020225139/http://www.mumbaimirror.com/others/sunday-read/The-jokes-not-just-on-YouTube/articleshow/49433084.cms#|archive-date = 2015-10-20|dead-url = no|df = }} It was kicked off by the release of an online video titled ''Creep Qawwali'', which was an advertisement for the start-up dating portal, ''Truly Madly''.{{Cite web|title = Why agencies should worry about AIB's new ad wing 'Vigyapanti' {{!}} ET BrandEquity|url = http://brandequity.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/advertising/aib-launches-ad-wing-vigyapanti-to-help-startups/49281904|website = ETBrandEquity.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151027232653/http://brandequity.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/advertising/aib-launches-ad-wing-vigyapanti-to-help-startups/49281904#|archive-date = 2015-10-27|dead-url = no|df = }} AIB started a news comedy series called ''On Air With AIB'' on the Star Network in October 2015. The 20-episode show (10 in English and 10 Hindi equivalents) was released on [[Hotstar]] first, followed by weekend airing on [[STAR World India]] and [[Star Plus]].{{Cite web|title = All India Bakchod TV Show AIB Start Date Time Broadcasting TV Channels|url = http://www.dekhnews.com/all-india-bakchod-tv-show-aib-start-date-time-broadcasting-tv-channels/|website = www.dekhnews.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151022180116/http://www.dekhnews.com/all-india-bakchod-tv-show-aib-start-date-time-broadcasting-tv-channels/#|archive-date = 2015-10-22|dead-url = no|df = }} They later returned with a second season on Hotstar. AIB also conducts screenwriting workshops under the banner AIB First Draft.{{Cite web |url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/improve-your-writing-skills-at-the-aib-first-draft-workshop/17851150# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-04-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170417072945/http://www.mid-day.com/articles/improve-your-writing-skills-at-the-aib-first-draft-workshop/17851150# |archive-date=2017-04-17 |dead-url=no |df= }} AIB's collaborators include [[Abish Mathew]], [[Kaneez Surka|Kaneez Surka,]] [[Varun Thakur]], [[Mallika Dua]] and [[Sumukhi Suresh]] among others. == On Air with AIB == [[File:AIB - If People Treated Other Illnesses Like They Treat Depression.webm|thumb|''AIB - If People Treated Other Illnesses Like They Treat Depression''

Hindi language video by AIB on depression awareness. Released on [[World Health Day]] 2017.|thumbtime=0:34]] On Air with AIB is a typical news comedy show that aims to find comedy in tragedy. Hosted by Rohan Joshi, Tanmay Bhat, Ashish Shakya and Gursimran Khamba, the show featured interviews, sketches and an examination of systemic issues that the country faces.{{Citation|title=On Air with AIB|date=2015-10-29|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5272790/plotsummary?ref_=tt_ov_pl|accessdate=2016-02-25}} The show has been co-hosted and written by [[Zakir Khan (comedian)|Zakir Khan]].{{Citation|title=A Sharpening of the Comedic Senses|date=2016-03-26|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/entertainment/a-sharpening-of-the-comedic-senses/article8398603.ece|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|access-date=2016-05-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160326093023/http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/entertainment/a-sharpening-of-the-comedic-senses/article8398603.ece#|archive-date=2016-03-26|dead-url=no|df=}} Season 2 of On Air with AIB is released only on Hotstar. {| class="wikitable" |+On Air with AIB: Season 1 - Episode List !Episode !English Title !Hindi Title !Airing date |- |1 |Why Be Good? |Zaban Sambhal Ke |29 October 2015 |- |2 |Aag - The Fire |Aag - The Fire |5 November 2015 |- |3 |Cop Blocked |Dar ke Aage Police Hai |12 November 2015 |- |4 |Space - The Final Frontier |Thoda Adjust Karo |19 November 2015 |- |5 |HIV/AIDS - Red Ribbon |HIV/AIDS - Nazar Hatao Jan Gavaon |26 November 2015 |- |6 |Monumental Screw Up |Purana Quila Nayi Vaat |3 December 2015 |- |7 |Delhi Smelly |Kaat Kaleja Delhi |10 December 2015 |- |8 |Ignorth East |Gharwale Baharwale |17 December 2015 |- |9 |Get High on Your Own Supply |Aakhri Nasha dil pe chadha |24 December 2015 |- |10 |Sex and the CSE |Phool aur Kante |31 December 2015 |} Season 2 started on 6 March 2017. {| class="wikitable" |+On Air with AIB: Season 2 - Episode List !Episode !Title !Airing date |- |1 |Nationalism Vs Anti-Nationalism |6 March 2017 |- |2 |Political Acronyms Are Dumb |8 March 2017 |- |3 |Back to School with Kanan and Biswa |10 March 2017 |- |4 |Purani Jeans Purani Soch |13 March 2017 |- |5 |Pseudoscience |15 March 2017 |- |6 |Trip Talk With Rahul |17 March 2017 |- |7 |Broad Bandh |20 March 2017 |- |8 |Fake News |27 March 2017 |- |9 |Kangarude |29 March 2017 |- |10 |2 Fast 2 Dumb with [[Kenny Sebastian]] |31 March 2017 |- |11 |Domestic Disturbance |3 April 2017 |- |12 |Straight Otta Noida |5 April 2017 |- |13 |One Tip, One Hand with Varun and Neville |7 April 2017 |- |14 |Science, Bitch! |10 April 2017 |- |15 |Aadhar Ya Na-Dhar |11 April 2017 |- |16 |D Pedo Media |12 April 2017 |} The third season started to stream on Hotstar from September 24, 2018. It follows the same format as established by the second season. On October 08, 2018 Hotstar made a public announcement from their official Twitter handle about cancellation of On air with AIB season 3 amid the charges of sexual harassment on minor girls{{Cite news|url=https://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/hotstar-cancels-on-air-with-aibs-third-season-as-comedy-group-battles-sexual-harrassment-charges-againsts-its-members-5341291.html|title=Hotstar cancels On Air with AIB's third season as comedy group battles sexual harrassment charges againsts [sic] its members- Entertainment News, Firstpost|work=Firstpost|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181009052654/https://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/hotstar-cancels-on-air-with-aibs-third-season-as-comedy-group-battles-sexual-harrassment-charges-againsts-its-members-5341291.html#|archive-date=2018-10-09|dead-url=no|df=}}. == Politics == In 2013, AIB uploaded a [[Satire|satirical]] video called ''Rape: It's Your Fault'', starring [[Kalki Koechlin]] and Juhi Pande. The video went [[Viral video|viral]] with over 6 million views, and started conversations about the way that rape victims in India are treated in the media and by law enforcement.{{Cite news|title = ‘Ladies, it’s your fault': Viral video calls out India’s culture of victim-blaming|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2013/09/23/ladies-its-your-fault-viral-video-calls-out-indias-culture-of-victim-blaming/|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = 2013-09-23|access-date = 2015-12-03|issn = 0190-8286|language = en-US|first = Rama|last = Lakshmi|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151209161534/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2013/09/23/ladies-its-your-fault-viral-video-calls-out-indias-culture-of-victim-blaming/#|archive-date = 2015-12-09|dead-url = no|df = }} AIB has been highly critical of [[Facebook]]'s [[Free Basics]] program, on the grounds that it violates [[net neutrality]]. In 2015, the group made three videos, all of which went viral, published on [[YouTube]], urging people to write to the [[Telecom Regulatory Authority of India]] (TRAI) to keep India's internet neutral towards contents and content providers and providing a substantial boost to the pro-net neutrality [[SaveTheInternet.in]] campaign. Later, TRAI supported net neutrality and ruled against differential data pricing based on content which resulted in ending [[zero-rating]] platforms in India including Free Basics and [[Airtel Zero]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/feb/08/india-facebook-free-basics-net-neutrality-row|title=India deals blow to Facebook in people-powered 'net neutrality' row|last=Soni|first=Aayush|date=2016-02-08|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-03-09|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312045157/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/feb/08/india-facebook-free-basics-net-neutrality-row#|archive-date=2017-03-12|dead-url=no|df=}}{{Cite news|url=http://qz.com/612129/the-lawyers-techies-and-comedians-who-fought-facebook-to-keep-indias-internet-free-and-open/|title=The lawyers, techies, and comedians who fought Facebook to keep India’s internet free and open|last=Punit|first=Itika Sharma|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-03-09|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161225111912/http://qz.com/612129/the-lawyers-techies-and-comedians-who-fought-facebook-to-keep-indias-internet-free-and-open/#|archive-date=2016-12-25|dead-url=no|df=}}{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/tech-news-technology/facebook-free-basics-ban-net-neutrality-all-you-need-to-know/|title=TRAI supports Net Neutrality, effectively bans Free Basics: All that happened in this debate|date=2015-12-29|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2017-03-09|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170219051531/http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/tech-news-technology/facebook-free-basics-ban-net-neutrality-all-you-need-to-know/#|archive-date=2017-02-19|dead-url=no|df=}}2016, they uploaded a satirical video called ''The Demonetisation Circus'' based on the [[Narendra Modi|Modi]] government's decision to [[2016 Indian banknote demonetisation|demonetise banknotes of Rs. 500 and Rs. 1000]]. The video exposed the facilities faced by the common public and the attitude of citizens towards their brethren in a satirical manner. [http://indianexpress.com/article/trending/viral-videos-trending/watch-aibs-satirical-take-on-demonetisation-and-its-many-promised-benefits-is-a-must-watch-4411627/] ==Controversy== ===AIB Knockout=== {{main article|AIB Knockout}} Akhilesh Tiwari, president of Balaji telefilms in Mumbai, filed a written complaint at Sogogot fire station on February 2015 for alleged use of good abusive language in the AIB knockout. The Mumbai police initiated a film into this complaint against the participants, ranging from Director [[Karan Johar]] to actors [[Arjun Kapoor]] and [[Ranveer Singh]]. An edited photo of the event was uploaded on [[facebook]] on 28 January 2015, covering the event that was held on December 28.{{cite news | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/AIB-roast-Police-complaint-lodged-against-Bollywood-stars-for-filthy-language/articleshow/46098072.cms | title=AIB roast: Police complaint lodged against Bollywood stars for filthy language | work=Times of India | date=2 February 2015 | agency=PTI | accessdate=3 February 2015 | location=Mumbai | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205075510/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/AIB-roast-Police-complaint-lodged-against-Bollywood-stars-for-filthy-language/articleshow/46098072.cms# | archive-date=2015-02-05 | dead-url=no | df= }} The government of [[Maharashtra]] ordered an inquiry against event organizers and participants.{{cite news | url=http://www.abplive.in/movies/2015/02/02/article491731.ece/Maharashtra-government-orders-inquiry-into-offensive-comedy-show | title=Maharashtra government orders inquiry into "offensive" comedy show | work=ABP Live | date=2 February 2015 | agency=PTI | accessdate=3 February 2015 | location=Mumbai | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203133414/http://www.abplive.in/movies/2015/02/02/article491731.ece/Maharashtra-government-orders-inquiry-into-offensive-comedy-show# | archive-date=2015-02-03 | dead-url=no | df= }} Bollywood actor [[Aamir Khan]] criticized the group's roast event. He said ‘I completely believe in freedom of speech but as creative persons we have to understand that we all have a certain responsibility towards society.’{{cite news|url=http://www.abplive.in/india/2015/02/10/article498644.ece/Aamir-Khan-lashes-out-at-AIB-roast|title=Aamir Khan lashes out at AIB roast|date=10 February 2015|work=ABP News|access-date=2015-02-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211122954/http://www.abplive.in/india/2015/02/10/article498644.ece/Aamir-Khan-lashes-out-at-AIB-roast|archive-date=2015-02-11|dead-url=yes|df=}} In response, [[Anurag Kashyap]] posted a link on his Facebook page showing Khan defending the DK Bose song from the movie ''Delhi Belly'', a film that Khan produced. Khan had said, "I have already informed my audiences that it is an adult film. Please do not go with your kids and those who have a problem with this kind of language shouldn't come either. I try my best to inform the audiences beforehand. Then they can decide themselves. If the audience is adult, they can decide themselves. So from my end I do all these things for my fans."{{cite news|url=http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/after-aamir-khans-aib-roast-putdown-anurag-kashyap-reminds-us-of-delhi-belly-738811|title=After Aamir Khans aib roast putdown anurag kashyap reminds us of delhi belly|date=11 February 2015|work=ABP News|access-date=2015-03-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150305030408/http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/after-aamir-khans-aib-roast-putdown-anurag-kashyap-reminds-us-of-delhi-belly-738811#|archive-date=2015-03-05|dead-url=no|df=}} AIB had provided a statutory warning at the beginning of the video describing the 18+ offensive nature of the content of the video. To ensure that people get the message, they made their ‘roast master’ [[Karan Johar]] repeat the warning. ===Sexual Harassment Allegations=== On 4th October 2018, stand-up comedian and popular YouTuber [[Utsav Chakraborty]], who works a freelancer with the comedy group All Indian Bakchod, has been accused of sending women lewd messages and photos via social message apps. The allegations against Utsav blew up when a Twitter user named Mahima Kukreja put up a Twitter post, accusing the comedian of sending her an unsolicited photo of gentalia and then pleading with her not to make his act public as it would "ruin" his career. {{Cite web |url = https://www.indiatoday.in/fyi/story/utsav-chakraborty-sexual-harassment-1355731-2018-10-04 |title = Comedian Utsav Chakraborty, once associated with AIB, accused of sexually harassing women |website = India Today |language = en |access-date = 2018-10-07 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181007053516/https://www.indiatoday.in/fyi/story/utsav-chakraborty-sexual-harassment-1355731-2018-10-04# |archive-date = 2018-10-07 |dead-url = no |df = }}. Most of the comedians within his circle knew about his behaviour of harassing minor girls including [[Tanmay Bhat]] but opted to keep quiet and work with him.{{Cite news |url = https://www.hindustantimes.com/tv/aib-accepts-tanmay-bhat-knew-of-sexual-harassment-claims-against-utsav-chakraborty-and-continued-working-with-him/story-AAU6307XSlqCeqZtgfj4nN.html |title = AIB accepts Tanmay Bhat knew of sexual harassment claims against Utsav Chakraborty and continued working with him |date = 2018-10-05 |work = The Hindustan Times |access-date = 2018-10-07 |language = en |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181006132327/https://www.hindustantimes.com/tv/aib-accepts-tanmay-bhat-knew-of-sexual-harassment-claims-against-utsav-chakraborty-and-continued-working-with-him/story-AAU6307XSlqCeqZtgfj4nN.html# |archive-date = 2018-10-06 |dead-url = no |df = }}. On 8th October 2018, Gursimran Khamba gave clarification on some sexual harassment allegations reported by an unknown girl. She accused Khamba of sexually assaulting her. Khamba, on the other hand, denied the allegation, claiming that the relationship was consensual. As a result of these allegations against AIB members, AIB's HR team announced that Tanmay Bhat would be stepping away from the business immediately, and Khamba would take a leave of absence.{{cite news |url = https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/me-too-founders-tanmay-bhat-gursimran-khamba-out-aib-until-further-notice-89629 |title = Me Too: Founders Tanmay Bhat, Gursimran Khamba out of AIB ‘until further notice’ |work = The News Minute |access-date = 2018-10-08 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181008175040/https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/me-too-founders-tanmay-bhat-gursimran-khamba-out-aib-until-further-notice-89629# |archive-date = 2018-10-08 |dead-url = no |df = }} == See also == * [[The Viral Fever]] * [[East India Comedy]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCzUYuC_9XdUUdrnyLii8WYg AIB on YouTube] [https://www.downloadanysong.com/song/udd-gaye--bacardi-house-party-sessions-rit Udd Gaye | Bacardi AIB on DownloadAnySong] {{Star Plus Shows}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bakchod, All India}} [[Category:YouTube channels]] [[Category:Comedy collectives]] [[Category:Indian web series]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Musical |name= As Thousands Cheer |image= As_thousands_cheer.jpg |caption= ''As Thousands Cheer'' 1998 cast |music= [[Irving Berlin]] |lyrics= Irving Berlin |book= [[Moss Hart]] |basis= |productions= 1933 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] <!-- Please do not include production-specific (acting, directing, etc.) awards --> |awards= }}
'''''As Thousands Cheer''''' is a [[revue]] with a book by [[Moss Hart]] and music and lyrics by [[Irving Berlin]], first performed in 1933. The revue contained satirical sketches and witty or poignant musical numbers, several of which became standards, including "[[Heat Wave (Irving Berlin song)|Heat Wave]]", "[[Easter Parade (song)|Easter Parade]]" and "Harlem on my Mind". The sketches were loosely based on the news and the lives and affairs of the rich and famous, and other people of the day, such as [[Joan Crawford]], [[John D. Rockefeller, Jr.]], [[Noël Coward]], [[Josephine Baker]], and [[Aimee Semple McPherson]].
==History== The revue was a successor to the creators' ''[[Face the Music (musical)|Face the Music]]'' and was [[Marilyn Miller]]'s last stage appearance before her death. It was also the first Broadway show to give an [[African-American]] star, [[Ethel Waters]], equal billing with whites.
Moss Hart said that he and Irving Berlin did not want to write the typical revue with "blackout sketches" and musical numbers, and they had the idea of doing a topical revue "right off the front pages of the newspapers." Berlin deferred his own fees as composer, lyricist, and theater owner, keeping the cost of the show to a "restrained" $96,000.<ref>Bergreen, p. 313.</ref>
==Synopsis== Each of the 21 scenes was preceded by a related newspaper headline, and the sketches poked fun a wide variety of subjects, including the marital woes of [[Barbara Hutton]], [[Gandhi]], and British royalty; the weather report was turned into a song ("Heat Wave");<ref>Bergreen, pp. 189 and 314.</ref> [[Herbert Hoover|President and Mrs. Hoover]] leaving the White House, with the President giving his cabinet a [[Bronx cheer (gesture)|Bronx cheer]]; "Supper Time", an African-American woman's lament for her lynched husband; [[John D. Rockefeller]] refusing to accept [[Radio City Music Hall]] as a birthday gift; commercials interrupting the singing during a Metropolitan Opera broadcast ([[P.D.Q. Bach]] later did this); a hotel staff falling under the influence of [[Noël Coward]]; and a [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] decision that says musicals cannot end with reprises, resulting in a new number, "Not For All The Rice In China" (satirizing Barbara Hutton's relationship with [[Mdivani|Alexis Mdivani]]), as a finale.<ref>Boardman, Gerald. ''A Chronicle of American Musical Theatre''.</ref>
==Selected musical numbers== *"Majestic Sails at Midnight" -- Helen Broderick, Leslie Adams, Jerome Cowan, Hal Forde, [[Harry Stockwell]] *"[[How's Chances?]]" -- Marilyn Miller, Clifton Webb *"The Funnies" -- Marilyn Miller *"[[Easter Parade (song)|Easter Parade]]"† -- Marilyn Miller, Clifton Webb *"Our Wedding Day" -- Marilyn Miller, Clifton Webb *"[[Heat Wave (Irving Berlin song)|Heat Wave Hits New York]]" -- Ethel Waters *"To Be Or Not To Be" -- Ethel Waters *"[[Supper Time]]" -- Ethel Waters *"Harlem on my Mind" -- Ethel Waters *"Lonely Heart" -- dance *"Not for All the Rice in China" -- Marilyn Miller, Clifton Webb
† ''Omitted from 1998 revival''
==Productions== The revue opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Music Box Theatre]] on September 30, 1933 and became a hit, running for 400 performances, which was rare during the [[Great Depression]]. It was staged by [[Hassard Short]] with choreography by [[Charles Weidman]]. The musical starred [[Helen Broderick]], [[Marilyn Miller]], [[Clifton Webb]] and [[Ethel Waters]], and featured [[José Limón]] as the lead dancer. The London-based version of the show, retitled ''Stop Press'', opened on February 21, 1935 at the [[Adelphi Theatre]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Green|first=Stanley|title=Encyclopedia Of The Musical Theatre|date=1980-03-22|publisher=Da Capo Press|page=16|isbn=978-0-306-80113-6}}</ref>
In 1934, [[Dorothy Stone (actress)|Dorothy Stone]] took over the roles played by Miller.
The [[Drama Department]] presented the revue at the [[off-Broadway]] Greenwich House Theater from June 2, 1998 through June 14, 1998. Directed by [[Christopher Ashley]] with musical staging by [[Kathleen Marshall]], the cast included [[Kevin Chamberlin]], [[Judy Kuhn]], [[Howard McGillin]], Paula Newsome, [[Mary Beth Peil]] and [[B. D. Wong]]. Reviews were extremely positive.<ref>[http://www.curtainup.com/thousand.html Curtain Up review] curtainup.com, June 19, 1998</ref> The show has had a number of other revivals both in the U.S. and internationally.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *[http://www.guidetomusicaltheatre.com/shows_a/as1000scheer.htm Description of the revue and list of scenes at guidetomusicaltheatre] *Bergreen, Laurence (1996). ''As Thousands Cheer: The Life of Irving Berlin''. Da Capo Press. {{ISBN|0-306-80675-4}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222451/http://www.rnh.com/theatricals/show.php?show_id=48 R&H Theatricals]
==External links== *{{ibdb show|id=1705|title=As Thousands Cheer}} *[http://www.lortel.org/LLA_archive/index.cfm?search_by=show&title=As%20Thousands%20Cheer Lortel listing 1998 revival] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928060206/http://www.musicalheaven.com/Detailed/495.html Information from the Musical Heaven website]
{{Irving Berlin}}

{{Infobox video game |title= Boom Blox Bash Party |image= Boom Blox Bash Party.jpg |caption = |developer=[[Amblin Entertainment]]
[[EA Los Angeles]] |publisher=[[Electronic Arts]] |producer=[[Robin Hunicke]] |designer=[[Steven Spielberg]] |composer= |engine= |released={{vgrelease|NA|19 May 2009|EU|29 May 2009|AU|18 June 2009|}} |genre=[[Puzzle video game|Puzzle]], [[Party game#Party video games|party game]] |modes=[[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms=[[Wii]] }} '''''Boom Blox Bash Party''''', '''''Boom Blox Smash Party''''' in non-English territories, is a [[Game physics|physics]]-based [[puzzle video game|puzzle]] [[video game]] developed by [[EA Los Angeles]] and [[Amblin Entertainment]] and published by [[Electronic Arts]] for the [[Wii]] [[video game console]]. It is a sequel to ''[[Boom Blox]]'', and was released on 19 May 2009 in North America and in Europe on 29 May 2009. The game features more than 400 levels, and players are able to download new levels and upload their own custom-created levels to share online. Its development began after the completion of its predecessor, and it was formally announced on 28 January 2009. As with the original game, this sequel was also designed by film director [[Steven Spielberg]]. The gameplay of ''Boom Blox Bash Party'' resembles the original's, but features new mechanics. It also has less emphasis on the shooting mode, which the developers commented was their least favorite mode of play in ''Boom Blox''. It was created as part of a deal between Electronic Arts and Steven Spielberg to make three original properties, though it does not count as one of the three original properties. As of April 2012, EA has shut down the online servers, meaning players can no longer upload and download user created games. ==Gameplay== [[File:Boom Blox Bash Party Underwater.PNG|thumb|left|An underwater scene]] ''Boom Blox Bash Party'' features similar gameplay to its predecessor. It features a new [[slingshot]] mechanic; the shooting mechanic is less prominent than in the first game.{{cite web |url=http://multiplayerblog.mtv.com/2009/01/29/ea-will-ask-steven-spielberg-to-make-a-boom-blox-level/ |title=EA Will Ask Steven Spielberg To Make A ‘Boom Blox’ Level |accessdate=2009-01-29 |last=Totilo |first=Stephen |date=2009-01-29 |work=MTV Multiplayer |publisher=MTV Networks}} The game includes new environments (such as [[underwater]] and [[outer space]]), new block shapes (such as cylinders and ramps), and more extensive multiplayer. ''Boom Blox Bash Party'' originally allowed players to upload levels, as well as download levels made by other players and [[Electronic Arts]].{{cite web |title=Quick Boom Blox Bash Party Interview |url=http://www.1up.com/do/newsStory?cId=3172525 |publisher=[[1UP.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-29 |date=2009-01-29 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Uploaded levels had to be reviewed by Electronic Arts, with any inappropriate content filtered out. However, a player could download any levels made by someone on their Wii Friends list. ''Boom Blox Bash Party'' did not feature [[Friend Code]]s, a common method of online play in [[Wii]] and [[Nintendo DS]] games.{{cite web|title=Spielberg, EA play "Boom Blox" sequel |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/technologyNews/idCATRE50S0P120090129 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=2009-01-28 |date=2009-01-28}} Some of the levels uploaded by EA include levels from the original ''[[Boom Blox]]''. The ability to upload and download levels ended on April 13, 2012 when EA shut down all of the servers.{{cite news|title=EA shutting down over a dozen game servers|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/ea-shutting-down-over-a-dozen-game-servers/1100-6366856/|accessdate=October 10, 2016|work=GameSpot|date=March 19, 2012}}{{cite news|last1=Schreier|first1=Jason|title=EA Takes Down Online Servers For Eleven Games|url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2012/03/ea-takes-down-online-servers-for-eleven-games/|accessdate=October 10, 2016|date=March 20, 2012}} ==Development== ''Bash Party'''s development was announced on 18 November 2008 by ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''.{{cite web |title=Electronic Arts shuts down Blueprint, making Boom Blox 2 |url=http://weblogs.variety.com/the_cut_scene/2008/11/electronic-arts.html |publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=2009-01-29 |date=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225161734/http://weblogs.variety.com/the_cut_scene/2008/11/electronic-arts.html |archivedate=2009-02-25 |df= }} It was announced for a Spring 2009 release{{cite web |title=EA and Steven Spielberg announce Boom Blox Bash Party |url=http://www.ea.com/read/20090129-bbp.xml |publisher=[[Electronic Arts]] |accessdate=2009-01-29 |date=2009-01-28}} as ''Boom Blox Bash Party'' on January 28, 2009 by [[EA Casual]]. The game was developed by [[Electronic Arts]] and [[Steven Spielberg]], just like its predecessor. It was a part of a 2005 deal between EA and Spielberg to make three original properties. It was conceived as soon as the original game was completed. Spielberg kept meeting with EA on ''Boom Blox'' on new ideas; producer [[Amir Rahimi]] commented that there was so much enthusiasm that "he could hardly stop them from doing a sequel." A feature which was cut in ''Boom Blox'' was not included in this game either. It was a head-tracking system, which would allow the player to use two [[Wii Remote]]s to control the game's camera with his or her head.{{cite web |title=GDC08: Boom Blox to include head tracking. Seriously. |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2008/02/21/gdc08-boom-blox-to-include-head-tracking-seriously/ |publisher=[[Joystiq]] |accessdate=2009-01-29 |date=2008-02-21}} Because the developers didn't receive the development hardware in time to implement it, [[Wii MotionPlus]] compatibility is not included. In an interview, it was stated that Steven Spielberg had sometimes expressed interest in making a ''Boom Blox'' movie, but an Electronic Arts spokesperson commented that this is all just [[brainstorming]]. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | width = 25em | MC = 86 (32 reviews){{cite news|title=''Boom Blox Bash Party'' Reviews|url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/wii/boombloxbashparty|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=2009-06-17}} | GSpot = 8.5/10 | IGN = 8.5/10{{cite web|url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/984/984737p2.html|title=Boom Blox Bash Party Review|first=Matt|last=Casmassina|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=May 19, 2009|accessdate=May 19, 2009}} | VG = 9/10{{cite news|title=''Boom Blox Bash Party'' Review|url=http://www.videogamer.com/wii/boom_blox_bash_party/review.html|first=Tom|last=Orry|date=2009-06-17|publisher=VideoGamer.com|accessdate=2009-06-17}} }} ''Bash Party'' has received generally favorable reviews from critics, holding an 86% on [[Metacritic]]. [[IGN]] awarded ''Bash Party'' an Editors' Choice award, giving it 8.5 out of 10. [[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4]]'s [[X-Play]] gave it 5 out of 5 stars.{{cite news|title=Boom Blox: Bash Party for Wii - G4tv|url=http://www.g4tv.com/games/wii/57017/boom-blox-bash-party/|accessdate=October 10, 2016|work=www.g4tv.com|agency=G4}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://boomblox.ea.com/ Official website] {{Steven Spielberg video games}} [[Category:Steven Spielberg]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Electronic Arts games]] [[Category:Puzzle video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Wii-only games]] [[Category:Wii Wi-Fi games]] [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]]

{{original research|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox video game |title=Bubble Ghost |image=Bubble Ghost Coverart.png |caption= |publisher=[[ERE Informatique]] (France)
[[Infogrames]] (UK, Europe)
[[Accolade (company)|Accolade]] (USA)
[[Pony Canyon]] (Japan) |developer=Christophe Andreani (ST)
[[Infogrames]] (ports)
Opera House (Game Boy) |designer=Christophe Andreani |engine= |composer=[[Hitoshi Sakimoto]] (Game Boy) |released= {{vgrelease|NA|1987}}{{vgrelease|NA|November 1, 1990 (Game Boy)}} |genre=[[Action video game|Action]] |modes=[[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms=[[Atari ST]] (original)
[[Amiga]], [[Amstrad CPC]], [[Commodore 64]], [[MS-DOS]], [[Apple IIGS]], [[Game Boy]] }} '''''Bubble Ghost''''' is a [[1987 in video gaming|1987]] [[video game]] created by Christophe Andreani and published by [[ERE Informatique]]. ==Gameplay== ''Bubble Ghost'' is a 2D arcade game. The player controls the ghost using the computer mouse and makes him blow at a bubble. The objective is to guide a bubble throughout a number of halls in a [[haunted house]]. If the bubble hits any walls or obstacles, then it will pop and the player loses a life. Obstacles include lit candles, electricity and fans. These can be all controlled by the ghost, who can wander around the level freely and [[Exhalation|blow]] at things - such as the bubble to add speed, the candle to put out the flame, or switches to turn them on or off. The ghost is controlled using the mouse: moving the mouse moves the ghost. A press on the left button of the mouse makes the ghost rotate to the left. A press on the right button of the mouse makes the ghost rotate to the right. A press on a keyboard key (Shift) makes the ghost blow. The game is made of 35 halls (levels). Each time the player makes the bubble exit a hall, he wins 1000 points + left bonus. Action on animation may add 5000 points to the player. The bonus is re-initialized at every new hall. A new bubble is added to the player account each time the bubble exits towards the top of the hall. ==Releases== The original ''Bubble Ghost'' was created by Christophe Andreani (design, programming) on an [[Atari ST]] computer. The game has been adapted for other computers throughout the world. Some years later, [[ERE Informatique]] was bought by [[Infogrames]]. Infogrames published a new version of ''Bubble Ghost'' with updated graphics, ''Bubble +'' (''Bubble Plus''). A [[Nintendo]] [[Game Boy]] version was published in 1990. It was the first French game adapted for the Game Boy. {{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} The original concept of ''Bubble Ghost'' was reused and modified in 2008 in the game ''[[Soul Bubbles]]'' for the [[Nintendo DS]]. {{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} ==Miscellaneous== Some graphic parts of the ''Bubble Ghost'' halls have a specific meaning: Hall #4: An advertisement for the French telematics server [http://www.troude.com/Pinky Pinky] by Godefroy Troude, and a wink to the video game ''[http://mercenarysite.free.fr Mercenary]'' by Paul Woakes published by [[Novagen Software|Novagen]]. Hall#5: The face of the author slightly modified. Hall#11: The face of the author appears with glasses (if the ghost is blowing in the ear, glasses disappear) and a wink at the video game ''[http://www.gamopat.com/article-5781231.html The Pawn]'' published by Rainbird. Hall#15: Another wink to the video game ''[http://mercenarysite.free.fr Mercenary]'' by Paul Woakes published by [[Novagen Software|Novagen]]. Hall#28: Two more winks to the video game ''[http://www.gamopat.com/article-5781231.html The Pawn]'' published by Rainbird. ==Gallery== Image:Bubble_ghost_st_hall04.gif|Bubble Ghost, Atari ST version, Hall#4 Image:Bubble_ghost_st_hall05.png|Bubble Ghost, Atari ST version, Hall#5 Image:Bubble_ghost_st_hall09.png|Bubble Ghost, Atari ST version, Hall#9 Image:Bubble_ghost_gb_hall03.png|Bubble Ghost, Game Boy version, Hall#3 ==Technical information== {{Unreferenced|section|date=October 2018}} The game was programmed in [[C (programming language)|C]] (editor and compiler: [[Megamax C]]) and 68000 [[assembly language]] on an [[Atari ST|Atari 1040 ST]] computer. The graphics were made with the [[DEGAS (software)|Degas Elite]] drawing software. The digital sound of the introductory page of the game ("Welcome to Bubble Ghost") was built using ST Replay. This is the author's voice. The other sound effects use the synthesizer inside the [[Atari ST]]. Here are some notes from the author when creating the game: Image:Bubble ghost doc01.jpg|Bubble Ghost, levels order Image:Bubble ghost doc02.jpg|Bubble Ghost, hall#9 design Image:Bubble ghost doc03.jpg|Bubble Ghost, ghost and bubble animation Image:Bubble ghost doc04.jpg|Bubble Ghost, game technical notes ==Press== Following French magazines have published ''Bubble Ghost'' review: *SVM Science et Vie Micro #45, December 1987 (Atari ST version) [http://www.abandonware-magazines.org/affiche_mag.php?mag=48&num=2237&images=oui Download magazine] *Tilt #49, December 1987 (Atari ST version) [http://www.abandonware-magazines.org/affiche_mag.php?mag=28&num=354&images=oui Download magazine] *ST Magazine #14, November/December 1987 (Atari ST version) [http://www.abandonware-magazines.org/affiche_mag.php?mag=6&num=815&images=oui Download magazine] *Micro News #6, November/December 1987 (Atari ST version) *Le Tatou #10, December 1987 (Atari ST version) *1ST (FirST) #4, December 1987 (Atari ST version) [http://www.abandonware-magazines.org/affiche_mag.php?mag=4&num=1142&images=oui Download magazine] *Jeux et Stratégie #48, December 1987 (Atari ST version) *Génération 4 #2, December 1987 (Atari ST version) [http://www.abandonware-magazines.org/affiche_mag.php?mag=27&num=389&images=oui Download magazine] *Amstrad Cent Pour Cent #1, {{Infobox broadcasting network | name = CHT MOD | image = | logo = | type = | branding = | established = | test card = | test of transmission = | airdate = | country = {{ROC}} | available = [[IPTV]] | founded = 2004 | founder = | ceo = | slogan = | motto = | tvstations = | tvtransmitters = | radiostations = | radiotransmitters = | market_share = | license_area = | headquarters = | broadcast_area = {{ROC}} | area = | nation = | regions = | erp = | owner = | parent = | key_people = | foundation = | launch_date = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | replaced = | replaced_by = | former_names = | digital = | analog = | servicename1 = | service1 = | servicename2 = | service2 = <!--......--> | servicename7 = | service7 = | callsigns = | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | affiliation = | affiliates = | groups = | former_affiliations = | webcast = | website = {{URL|mod.cht.com.tw}} | footnotes = }} '''CHT MOD''' (Multimedia On Demand of Chunghwa Telecom, {{lang-zh|中華電信MOD}}) is a Taiwan-based consumer IPTV service, operated by [[Chunghwa Telecom]]. Up to now, The current number of customers reached 1.48 million.
==History== In January 2003, '''Chunghwa Telecom''' applied to [[Government Information Office, Executive Yuan|the Information Office]] of the Executive Yuan for IPTV business. At the end of November 2003, Chunghwa Telecom approved the launch of IPTV business by the Information Office of the Executive Yuan, named "Chunghwa Telecom MOD".
In February 2004, the Information Bureau of the Executive Yuan was issued to Chunghwa Telecom an IPTV operation license.
On 3 March, 2004, Chunghwa Telecom held MOD opening [[news conference|press conference]], Chunghwa Telecom Chairman [[Hochen Tan]] declared: "MOD users this year, 100,000, three year a million!”.
On 18 August 2005, Chunghwa Telecom MOD renamed to "Chunghwa Telecom Big TV", emphasizing interactive TV and on-demand video function, slogan was "our TV station, rich and exciting". In 2006, Chunghwa Telecom big TV changed its name to "Chunghwa Telecom multimedia content transmission platform", referred to as "Chunghwa Telecom MOD".
